qas.question: What is the largest mammal to live in the highest altitudes?
How high have the Alpine Ibex been sighted?
What animal that live in the Alps are classified as antelopes?
What year was the last brown bear recorded to have been killed?

context: The largest mammal to live in the highest altitudes are the <a0_0>alpine ibex<a0_0/>, which have been sighted <a1_0>as high as 3,000 m (9,843 ft)<a1_0/>. The ibex live <a2_0>in caves<a2_0/> and descend to eat the succulent alpine grasses. Classified as antelopes, <a3_0>chamois<a3_0/> are smaller than ibex and found throughout the Alps, living above the tree line and are common in the entire alpine range. Areas of the eastern Alps are still home to brown bears. In Switzerland the canton of Bern was named for the bears but the last bear is recorded as having been killed in <a4_0>1792<a4_0/> above Kleine Scheidegg by three hunters from Grindelwald.
